intro: Oxytropis pagobia, commonly known as the Pagobian locoweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright stems and small, clustered leaves. The plant produces yellow flowers in late spring to early summer, which are typically pea-shaped and arranged in dense spikes. Oxytropis pagobia is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils and open plains. It is known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock.
